item.title: What motivates me (I think)
item.description: What motivates me (I think) ðŸ”—2 things Variety Speed Variety ðŸ”—I have noticed about myself that I like heterogeneity whether it comes to programming or food or games. They are like flavours I want to try and I want to try all of them. It helps me grow as an individual. Its the same reason why I tried Object oriented programming when I was a hardcore functional programmer, why I mix my food unevenly so that every bite will taste different and why I explore every part of the game so that I don’t miss out on an experience.

item.description: Your best friends in Emacs ðŸ”—In emacs, You are either ðŸ”— Invoking a function through a key press Invoking a function manually Describe Mode1 C-h m ðŸ”—Describe mode gives you a list of all enabled Minor modes, functions in the major mode & all their key binds. item.title: My Editor Journey Till Now
item.description: My Editor Journey Till Now ðŸ”—What did I start with? ðŸ”—2018 My first editor was Emacs1. Why did I choose emacs? I couldn’t figure out how to exit Vim2. I got really into programming with Scheme3. And I liked it so much I decided to choose the editor with its roots in it. Learning emacs was just getting comfortable with its keybinds. The power of emacs comes from extensibility. Although I am a casual lisp programmer, I never bothered to learn elisp and extend emacs to my liking.

item.title: Why I like Smalltalk - Part 1 of 100 - Documentation
item.description: Why I like Smalltalk: Part 1 of 100 - Documentation ðŸ”—Smalltalk Documentation follows CRC1(Class, Responsibilities & Collaborators) ðŸ”— For those who don’t know what CRC is, it’s a tool that helps design objects. A CRC card consists of Class name at the top, responsibilities on the left side & collaborators on the right. Since a card models only one object, it enables rapid prototyping. It is feasible to go through many iterations before settling on an implementation.
